# Hi campers. We are archiving the Wiki room and moving everyone over to our new [Contributors](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Contributors) room.

There are several reasons why we're doing this:
1. it will facilitate more cross-discipline collaboration 
2. it will give everyone a better idea of what contributors are working on
3. it will be more lively (and chat should be lively)

We will archive this public room in a few days, close it, then release the message history of this (and hundreds of other archived rooms) as open data. 

So join me over here: https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Contributors

# CamperBot

Hi, I'm **[CamperBot](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/freecodecamp/wiki/camperbot)**! I can help you in this chatroom :smile:

### Basic Commands:

- `find TOPIC` find all entries about topic. e.g. `find js`
- `wiki TOPIC` show contents of topic page
- `thanks @username` send brownie points to another user
- `about @username` shows info on that user
- `Algorithm BONFIRENAME` info on a Algorithm

@/all for anyone of the wiki mods interested on adding the articles  :point_up: [July 2, 2016 3:29 PM](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Wiki?at=57781610cdab7a1f4fcf0db0)
Also we are using the `forum` branch for this chances, do not use any other. Always make sure to make the PR against this branch, and to sync the branch before you make new changes.

If you need help figuring out where to put the article or if you feel a category is needed then let me know and I'll create it for you.

I think the standar woudl be to:

### Pull Request:
- Assign all wiki mods, i leave Justing and a few others out as they will not be activellyw orking on it. This is mostly to let them knwo the status, I also assign @QuincyLarson for that reason too.
- The PR would remove the articles that have been added to the forum and no longer need changes.

### Forum
- Select the right section and subcategory for the article.
- Copy and paste the article with the same name as the heading in the article, if some alterations are needed, feel free to, so it reads more fluid, there is a limit of 15 characters for the title so those with shorter name will require a new title.
- Save the post, then make it a wiki and if you can, make it use staff color, if no is fine.
- Change ownership to me, at this point I can add the staff color if needed.
- Copy the full url of the new wiki article and replace it on the articles that referenced the old article. This can be done with a search and replace on the whole project. I use atom for it. Feel free to use whatever tool you have available.
- Once you are done adding articles, then save then commit the changes on the branch and follow the steps on the PR above.

## :point_right: [challenge accessing nested arrays in json  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/challenge-accessing-nested-arrays-in-json)
# Challenge Accessing Nested Arrays in JSON

As we have seen in earlier examples, JSON objects can contain both nested objects and nested arrays. Similar to accessing nested objects, Array bracket notation can be chained to access nested arrays.

Here is an example of how to access a nested array:

```javascript
var ourPets = { 
  "cats": [
    "Meowzer",
    "Fluffy",
    "Kit-Cat"
  ],
  "dogs": [
    "Spot",
    "Bowser",
    "Frankie"
  ]
};
ourPets.cats[1]; // "Fluffy"
:pencil: [read more about challenge accessing nested arrays in json on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/challenge-accessing-nested-arrays-in-json)

Hi. I write tech articles on Medium. Do you folks accept publication requests ?

To answer questions @koustuvsinha and @atjonathan asked:

Only campers who have trust level 1 or higher can modify wiki articles. The only way to become trust level 1 or higher is to participate actively in the forum for several hours. Any existing wiki contributors who immediately want to become trust level 1 can ask Rafael - he has the power to change trust level. 

Here are some of the reason we should migrate our wiki articles to the forum:

1) Not very many people access our wiki. Our wiki is only accessed about 5,000 times a month right now (less than 0.01% of page views). I think this is because they have to click the wiki and navigate within the wiki. With our forum, we can add articles in their relevant categories. They are much more likely to be organically discovered, and will be viewed much more as a result.

2) Our forum uses much more sophisticated search than our wiki's search, and wiki articles will show up in Forum searches - probably quite highly as they are likely to be hearted much more than normal posts due to their comprehensive nature. This will also translate into more campers viewing these articles.

3) It will be much easier to create new wiki articles and improve existing articles.  The workflow is just a few clicks. We'll still have version history for these articles, and it will be difficult to vandalize them (since you have to reach trust level 1 to edit them).

4) People will be able to reply directly to wiki articles with further questions and discussions of how they can be improved - suggestions which can ultimately be added to the wiki article (and easily, too).

In short, moving wiki articles to the forum should significantly increase the amount of campers who see these articles. We've all worked quite hard to create these articles as a resource for campers. Let's get them in front of as many campers as possible.

```
# fetch all remote repos and delete any deleted remote branches
$ git fetch --all --prune

# switch to `master` branch

# reset local `master` branch to match `upstream` repo's `master` branch
$ git reset --hard upstream/master

# push changes to your forked wiki repo
$ git push origin master
```

## :point_right: [freecodecamp fork local  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/freecodecamp-fork-local)
# How to Fork and maintain a Local Instance of Free Code Camp

If you plan to write a [Pull Request for Free Code Camp](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/FreeCodeCamp-Guide-Pull-Request), you will almost certainly need a local copy of the site. Having a local copy of the site will give you additional capability with Git that are not available via the GitHub browser interface, including updating your fork and rebasing/squashing commits.

This guide will cover how to fork the FCC project, clone a local copy, and how to maintain your fork. All Git commands will be given for the command line, which we strongly recommend that you use, but most commands can be executed in a graphical Git environment as well.

:pencil: [read more about freecodecamp fork local on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/freecodecamp-fork-local)

## :point_right: [angular keep data in sync  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/angular-keep-data-in-sync)
# Keep Data in sync

Say you want something to show up on the user view when you add it to the database. A new _thing_ object will instantly show up in an _ng-repeat_ loop in your HTML view if you simply add it to your local array with

```javascript

$scope.awesomeThings.push(newThing);
```

But you'll still need to add it to your database collection. Add it to your collection with

```javascript

$http.post('/api/things', newThing);
```

## :point_right: [algorithm check for palindromes  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/algorithm-check-for-palindromes)
# Algorithm Check for Palindromes

![](https://i.imgur.com/ozDWKEi.jpg)  

:triangular_flag_on_post: Remember to use [**`Read-Search-Ask`**](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/FreeCodeCamp-Get-Help) if you get stuck. Try to pair program :busts_in_silhouette: and write your own code :pencil:

### :checkered_flag: Problem Explanation:

Our goal for solving this problem is tidying up the string passed in, and checking whether it is in fact a palindrome.

- If you are unsure of what a palindrome is, it is a word or phrase that when reversed spells the same thing forwards or backwards. A simple example is `mom`, when you reverse the letters, it spells the same thing! Another example of a palindrome is `race car`. When we take out anything that is not a character it becomes `racecar` which is the same spelled forwards or backwards!

Once we have determined whether it is a palindrome or not we want to return either `true` or `false` based on our findings.

#### Relevant Links

- [String.prototype.replace](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/JS-String-Prototype-Replace)
- [String.prototype.toLowerCase](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/JS-String-Prototype-ToLowerCase)

:pencil: [read more about algorithm check for palindromes on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/algorithm-check-for-palindromes)

The only trade off for those changes are the easy of use/handling. It will be harder for those who are not at a certain level of html and markdown, but the point was to use markdown only to make it as easy as possible for contributors, long filenames are a nightmare to categorize and organize, all lowercase filenames are not an issue if we would had stuck to it from the begining  but also makes it harder to distinguis between a sentence with  parenthesis and a link unles we also go back to absolute links which are more prone to url typos.

So, I suggest we make a solid plan on everything before we make further changes as they also affect the FCC in some cases (help files, official files that get links from the site, challenge articles which are opened automatically on the right one when the wiki is called (WIP))

Which is also why I'm posponing the directory structure change until the wiki generator is fully working.

Varying from it would work against the purpose of using it, if so it would be easier to to have all names in lowercase so we don't have to convert it ourself ont eh script, use absolute url so we don't have to convert them either, and actually use html for links so we don't have to worry about coming up with a solution that would make all external linsk open in a new tab and fcc links on the same page. Also we would remove articel titles because they appear double onteh wiki and we can just make the filename the title as it was before, which would mean whole sentences in most cases as teh filename.

- Looks Good
- Standard (custom) format for all our articles
- Easier to handle when we have tow ork with regex
- Whatever else I have said in the past that I can't remember at the moment but should be burried int he history

# Building applications with React and Flux

This is designed to run in a c9 environment.

Once installed, enter `npm install` into the bash terminal. Then type `gulp` from the bash terminal.

Your React development environment is now ready.

The environment will compile React JSX, Lint JSX and JS with ESlint, Bundle your JS and CSS files, Migrate the built app to the dist folder, and run a dev web-server.

# Free Code Camp Pull Request

**What is a Pull Request?**

A pull request (PR) is a method of submitting proposed changes to the Free Code Camp Repo (or any Repo, for that matter). You will make changes to copies of the files which make up Free Code Camp in a personal fork, then apply to have them accepted by Free Code Camp prop er.

## :point_right: [campsites  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/campsites)
![Photograph from a Toronto Campsite Coffee-and-Code Session](http://i.imgur.com/Elb3dfj.jpg)

Free Code Camp Campsites represent a localized experience of our community. These Facebook groups are the place to organize Coffee-and-Code style events, pair program locally in hack sessions, or share news about other coding-related events in your area. 

Whether you live in a major metropolitan area, or a small town, we encourage you to join or create your campsite to meet other busy people learning to code. 

Here are some helpful links:

[Complete Alphabetical List of Campsites](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/List-of-Free-Code-Camp-city-based-Campsites)

[How to Create a New Campsite for your City](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/How-to-create-a-Campsite-for-your-city)

[Jumpstart Your Campsite with Coffee-and-Code](http://blog.freecodecamp.com/2015/09/jump-start-your-local-campsite-with-coffee-and-code.html)

[5 Steps to a Successful Meetup](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/5-Steps-to-organizing-a-successful-Campsite-event)

-------
See also:
[Campsite assets and promotional materials](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/assets/tree/master/Campsite%20materials)

I am curious to understand why this process is not automated

---
* Install all pacages with npm install
* Initialize and update the submodules npm run init-pages
* Clean and create the structure for the pages with npm run create-struc
* Build with npm run build
* Then copy the assets with npm run copy-assets
* Copy the templates with npm run copy-templates
* Run a local instance with npm run start. This will serve it on http://0.0.0.0:8000/
* When satisfied with your changes, do npm run save-pages to update the gatsby wiki. * This will commit changes with the date as the commit message "Page built on date +"%d-%m-%Y %T"

Yes ok. I guess Quincy meant that we should keep that free from underlying service, because if for some reason we need to switch our links to other services, like IDE One, in future - the reader doesn't need to bother about these things.

Also, won't work uniformly with C# articles. There, we are using dotnetfiddle.

I guess the question is do we go with separate name as needed, where needed (like REPL It! when we are using REPL, or JSBIin It! when we are using JSBin etc.); or do we go with a uniform tag "Run it in your browser!"

I think clearly stating the name is good, because other than product placement; we can clearly communicate to the reader what would happen when they click on the link. As in which site they would be taken to.

## :point_right: [quick tip keep data in sync  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/quick-tip-keep-data-in-sync)
Say you want something to show up on the user view when you add it to the database. A new *thing* object will instantly show up in an *ng-repeat* loop in your HTML view if you simply add it to your local array with  

~~~javascript

$scope.awesomeThings.push(newThing);
~~~

But youтАЩll still need to add it to your database collection. Add it to your collection with  

~~~javascript

$http.post('/api/things', newThing);	

~~~
But wait! YouтАЩll soon realize that while all the other things in your *$scope.awesomeThings* array have unique ids assigned by MongoDB (under the *thing.\_id* property), your *newThing* object will not, which will make it hard for you at some point to make database actions on it (deleting it from your database requires you to use its *._id* property). So what youтАЩll want to do after you add it to your *$scope.awesomeThings* array (because we want it to show up on the userтАЩs page immediately). Altogether, your code to add a newThing to your local array and database will look like:

~~~javascript
$scope.awesomeThings.push(newThing);
$http.post('/api/things', newThing).success(function(thatThingWeJustAdded) {
	$scope.awesomeThings.pop(); // let's lose that id-lacking newThing 
:pencil: [read more about quick tip keep data in sync on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/quick-tip-keep-data-in-sync)

## :point_right: [google app engine fedora with python  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/google-app-engine-fedora-with-python)
# How to Run Google App Engine in Fedora using python

This article covers step by step guide to install Google App Engine on your Fedora Operating System using python.

- Follow the steps in this documentation by [Google.](https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/python/#uploading_the_application)

  Testing the application as given in the above document may not work for many.

  So, try [this](http://stackoverflow.com/a/16970921) as given by Brice Lin.

  Also, follow the deployment strategy as provided by Brice Lin. To do this open another terminal (if you wish).

- Before deploying, you have to create the project in the Google Cloud Platform. Follow the steps from  [Uploading the app](https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/python/#uploading_the_application)
- But still following the above deployment strategy may not work for many. And an error like this may follow:

  ```
  ERROR appcfg.py:2396 An error occurred processing file '': HTTP Error 400: Bad Request Unexpected HTTP status 400. Aborting. Error 400: --- begin server output --- A version or backend parameter is required. --- end server output ---
  ```

This error occurs because of the missing Version statement in file **app.yaml**.  So add `version: 1`  in the **app.yaml** file in the application repository. Here, `helloworld` is the repository.  Now it will work.  Happy Coding & Making Application.
:pencil: [read more about google app engine fedora with python on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/google-app-engine-fedora-with-python)

## :point_right: [wiki become a mod  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/wiki-become-a-mod)
# Requirements to become a wiki Moderator

There are many ways to contribute to the [wiki](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/Wiki) without being part of the [Senior Group](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/Wiki-Senior-Mods). However, if you want to become one, there are certain requirements that you must meet first:

- **Be Active:** You must have been actively contributing to the wiki. This means:

  - You have been creating new articles.
  - You have been improving existing articles.
  - You have been helping mods and other contributors with their pull request.
  - You have been active in the official [Wiki chat room](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Wiki).

  You don't have to complete all of them but the most you check from this list the better your chances are. This shows that you are interested and committed and not just helping briefly and then vanish.

- **Know your domain:** You must have a decent command of [Git](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/Git-Resources) command line and desktop app, along with enough experience submitting pull request that are fully compliant with our [guidelines](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE). This means you also need to be familiar with [contributing from a browser](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/Wiki-Contribute-Online). This will show that you can handle your own and help other with any issues they might have with their pull request and using Git/github.

- **Reach out:** Once you have completed the requirements from steps one and two, feel free to contact [Rafase282](https://gitter.im/Rafase282) and kindly ask to join. Chances are that you are already well known whiting the wiki community and he has approached you first. If that is not the case then don't hesitate to show what you can bring to the team.

  **Note** If you contact any of the _senior moderators_ prior to achieving the requirements or directly send a request to join via github, it will be immediately rejected without previous communication.

If you are accepted then you will be officially introduced to the team and gain access to the exclusive perks such as being able to merge a pull request, assign team members to pull request and more.

## :point_right: [git rebase  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/git-rebase)
**Were you referred to this page to get your PR accepted? Scroll right [to the bottom](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/git-rebase#git-rebase-at-fcc) then!**

`git rebase` is an extremely useful tool that is all about rewriting git history, though most commonly used to *squash* multiple commits into one. While useful in this scenario, this is not the only function that the `git rebase` command can perform. It in fact proves to be far more useful when used for the intended function that its name suggests: to essentially *rebase* a branch. Let me explain what I mean by that.

Let us say that you have a repository such as this:

```
                                                  --- Commit 5 ----------- auth branch
                                                /               
                                               --- Commit 4 -------------- dev branch 
                                             /
 --- Commit 1 ---- Commit 2 ---- Commit 3 -------------------------------- master branch
```

If you wanted to merge the `auth` branch with the `dev` branch, git will throw an error at you because your `auth` branch is out-of-date: it doesn't account for Commit 4. You'll have to bring your branch up-to-date.

Git provides you with two methods to do this: the `merge` command and the `rebase` command. For an exploration of the `merge` command, visit the relevant wiki article: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/git-merge

Let's run `rebase` now:
```
:pencil: [read more about git rebase on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/git-rebase)

```js
[ '# Using Anonymous Functions for Private Namespacing in your JS Apps
',
  ' Using Anonymous Functions for Private Namespacing in your JS Apps',
  index: 0,
  input: '# Using Anonymous Functions for Private Namespacing in your JS Apps

Let's take a look at what a namespace is when it comes to building JavaScript applications and some of the benefits from using a private namespace when building your apps.

**Please note that this article references anonymous self-executing functions.   If you're unaware of what this is, please read this excellent article by Noah Stokes: [Self-Executing Anonymous Functions or How to Write Clean Javascript](http://esbueno.noahstokes.com/post/77292606977/self-executing-anonymous-functions-or-how-to-write). This article will go into detail about anonymous self-executing functions.** 

## What is a Namespace?

To put it simply, a namespace is just a section of code that has its own space. When you first begin writing JS apps, you generally just type the code out and run it.  This puts all of the code into what's known as the **global namespace**, which contains all of the code for the window you're working in. 

If you keep all of your code in the **global namespace**, though, you can run into problems with collisions, naming conventions, etc. especially in large JS applications/games.  

Let's take a look at an example of how using only the **global namespace** to develop a game is a bad idea.

So, let's say we have a game that is keep tracking of the points that the player has:

```javascript
var points = 0;
```

 A lot of games track points to add a competitive edge to the game.  By simply typing that line into a script, we've created a variable named *points* that can track the points gained by the user.

And that's all fine and well, but let's say that we have a more advanced user playing the game.  This user knows how to look at the source of a web page, and so this person takes a peek at the source behind the JS game and realizes that the *points* variable is just sitting there in the **global namespace**.  An evil smirk descends across their face as they contemplate the points they can achieve!  They decide that they don't want to wait to beat some baddies up, or smash some mushrooms, or what have you, to rack up a bunch of points.  They want their points now!  Well, how does *a quadrillion billion million* points sound?!  So, they load up the console on their favorite browser, and simply type into the console:

```javascript
points = 34750925489459203859095480917458059034;
```

Once the user hits enter, the *points* variable is updated in the game. Now, the user has a truly humongous, and likely unrealistic, amount of points in the game, and he can brag to his friends that no one can possibly beat his awesome score.  

So, how do we prevent this from occurring? This is where **private namespaces** come into play.  

## Private Namespaces

**Private namespaces** allow developers to put their code into sections (or **namespaces**).  These sections operate independently of each other but can still read and write from the **global namespace**. 

To break this down into simpler terms from a real life scenario, let's say you are working in an office building.  You have your own office, and you see others with their own offices.  Each office is locked, and only the person who owns the office has a key to this office.  Let's also say that you have some type of new super lock that makes your office impenetrable by any other person in the building.  Let's consider the office building itself as the **global namespace** and each office as a **private namespace**.  You don't have access to anyone else's office nor do they have access to yours.  But, each one of you have access to the rest of the office building, whether that's getting coffee, grabbing a snack, etc.  Each one of you can grab something from the **global namespace** (or create/modify something there), but you can't create/modify/grab anything from each other's office
```

@meetmangukiya another metric would probably help you understand better. This is the [CPython repo mirror](https://github.com/python/cpython), which is the most common form of Python. 

Python is a language, a set of specificiations, and it is implemented in C; and this is the one we most commonly use.

Then there is [PyPy](https://github.com/mozillazg/pypy), which is an implementation of Python in Python itself (about 95% raw Python). This is faster than CPython.

Then , Microsoft has an implementation of Python, in .NET framework. It's called [IronPython](http://ironpython.net/).

And then, there is [Jython](http://www.jython.org/), implementation of Python on JVM.

Finally, there is [Pyston](https://github.com/dropbox/pyston), another implementation of Python, by Dropbox.

I think this should tell you how popular Python is, in the industry.

Oh! God!!!!

@meetmangukiya since you brought up the concept of speed; yes, Python is indeed slow. It is about 100 times slower than C or Go. But for most applications, you don't need that kind of speed.

I was watching this talk by someone from Mozilla (wish I had the link!). They found Python to be slow, and switched to Go. The speed was awesome, and then their project started to grow.

It got difficult to predict the system behavior, their test coverage went down to 64%.

They switched back to Python, and now they had 100% test coverage, and the code was more readable, maintainable, and above all; predictable. 

However, there were some parts of the application, that were slow and also bottlenecks of the application. So, they implemented some of those with PyPi and Some of those in C/C++. Python gives you native C-plugin writing API, so you can write parts of your system in C/C++, and speed up your bottlenecks. For most of the codebase, Python is simply too easy of a solution.

@meetmangukiya Python is used mainly for
- System programming. Try booting your Linux or Mac after removing the pre-installed Python. You would get a kernel panic.
- Sysadmin tasks. It's a replacement for shell script, and most installers are written in Python. Take Node JS for example. One of the requirements to install it from source, is to have Python. Similarly, if you want to batch deploy something, chances are, that deployer is written in Python. Ansible, for example.
- Data Science. Libraries like `panda`, `numpy`, `scipy` lets you do complex analytic and mathematical tasks. Most Data Science courses in unis use Python. It's very popular in academia. Of course, R is there as well, and R vs Python is a very active debate.
- Web development. Python has big framework like Django, and microframeworks like Flask, Bottle, web.py, Pyramid etc. Sites like YouTube, Instagram, Quora, Reddit, Bitbucket, Collabedit and tons of others just like it; use Python web frameworks. Google App Engine is written in Python (I am not sure about this one though).

Python is an easy to pick up language, and currently a lot of unis are offering this as beginners language. Python community enforces strict standard on how to get something done - meaning, unlike JS, there is always only one way to do something. 

And the Python documentation is a piece of art. If you have any trouble in Python, just Google it. Usually the first link would have a detailed explanation for whatever you are looking for.

@abhisekp let me explain to you in a way, that you can easily remember. US has four time zones.

If people are living in California, they are near the pacific, and on the west coast. Their timezone is Pacific and at this time of year; it would be 12 hour 30 minutes behind our time. So just subtract 30 minutes and invert the time by 12 hours.

Next time zone, east to it, is Mountain time zone. 11 hour 30 minutes behind us.

The next one is Central time zone, 10 hour 30 minutes behind us. Chicago, Texas etc. places are in this time zone.

The last one is the Eastern time zone, 9 hour 30 minutes behind our timezone. East coast cities, close to Atlantic, are here. New York, Boston etc.

Now remember that 6 months of the year, due to daylight saving, all clocks in US would be forwarded by 1 hour. Currently it's undergoing that. So, basically the actual times or standard ties are 1 hour behind what you are seeing right now.

To summarize
- Pacific Daylight Saving Time or PDT = 12 hr 30 minutes behind our time.
- Mountain Daylight saving Time or MDT = 11 hr 30 minutes behind IST
- Central daylight saving Time or CDT = 10 hr 30 minutes behind IST
- Eastern Daylight saving Time or EDT = 9 hr 30 minutes behind IST

And, as for standard times
- PST = IST - 13:30
- MST = IST - 12:30
- CST = IST - 11:30
- EST = IST - 10:30

@alayek actually there is another reason not to use any non-standard label names. When searching for projects based on labels in 3rd party project searching websites, these non-standard labels won't show up in the results.
Some standard labels such as
- `bug`
- `help wanted`
- `documentation`
- `easy`
- `enhancement`
- `feature`

people search for projects based on these label naming scheme in 3rd party Github project searching sites such as see the links in http://24pullrequests.com

So better not to use any other label names. If we do, then waffle will also have a nervous breakdown :P

So before I work on the repo I need to do the following
```
# fetch all remote repos and delete any deleted remote branches
$ git fetch --all --prune

# switch to `master` branch
$ git checkout master

# reset local `master` branch to match `upstream` repo's `master` branch
$ git reset --hard upstream/master

# push changes to your forked wiki repo
$ git push origin master
```

## :point_right: [select issues for contributing using labels  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/select-issues-for-contributing-using-labels)
In this article you can find labels (see the table below) used to categorize the variety of issues submitted to FCC. The labels range from **bugs** to **questions** to **curriculum requests**. For example, if an issue has a ***Wiki*** label, you can create a Wiki article about that issue - after reading the [Wiki Style Guide](http://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/Wiki-Style-Guide). 

You can use labels to help you choose which issues to click on, rather than randomly clicking to find one of interest to you. Of course, you can work on and submit PRs for issues without labels. How ever you choose an issue, please be sure to read [Guidelines for Contributing](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/blob/staging/CONTRIBUTING.md) before submitting any pull requests.

Check out the table below for the list of FreeCodeCamp issue labels, along with descriptions (work in progress). Thanks @bugron, @ahstro, @benschenker, for compiling this list of labels and descriptions.

Note: The labels ***blocked***, ***confirmed***, and ***QA*** are also tied to [Waffle](https://waffle.io/freecodecamp/freecodecamp), a management system for FCC (GitHub) issues, and are automatically added and removed by it.

| Label              | Description | 
| ------------------ | ----------- | 
| accessibility      | This is used for issues that don't necessarily break the site, but make it harder to use (like when tests used to evaluate while you typed would flicker the whole screen). Also, relevant to enabling the site to be usable for those who may have vision impairment or disabilities.|
| accounts           | Camper has a problem with his/her FCC account, such as login problems, losing progress, or profile page is missing some solutions.|
| beta               | The issue is related to FCC's beta site.|
| bike shedding      | Requests which are trivial or essentially irrelevant to the purposes of the site. In other words issues that have no real consequence yet people insist on spending cycles on them.|
| blocked            | When an issue should not be worked on, due to waiting for the creatorтАЩs response, more information, or the issue is stale.|
| bug                | Confirmed and reproducible bug in FCC's code and not only, for example, in Internet Explorer.
| chrome             | The issue can only be reproduced in Google Chrome.|
| confirmed          | The reported issue has been verified. (It basically says the issue creator has successfully communicated how to replicate the issue, but no one has started working toward a fix).|
| curriculum request | Relates to everything that is requested to be added to current curriculum. The issue requests a new challenge, adding more explanation to a challenge, etc.|
| device specific    | The issue presents only for a particular device (smartphone, tablet, desktop, etc).|
:pencil: [read more about select issues for contributing using labels on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/select-issues-for-contributing-using-labels)

Also, after telling you about the script I decided to study it (I'm stuck ont he issue I mentioned onthe description anyways) and turns out that there was a lot of repeated code so i was able to add it to the package.
initializes and updates the submodules, so they will be populated with the latest version, then checkout the internal files and do some other work.

That is what this does I belive `"init-pages": "git submodule init && git submodule update --remote && cd wiki-master && git checkout master && cd ../wiki-gh-pages && git checkout gh-pages && cd .. && chmod 744 *.sh && mkdir -p pages/ && rm -rf ./pages/* && node create_structure",`

@Rafase282 yes. That means `git add <submodule-dir>` won't be required
this shud only be done if they're updated automatically using scripts
@abhisekp ^
[this](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki-generator/blob/master/deploy.sh) is the script I was talkign about.

The issue before was that someone forcedpushed and removed the commit so it was pointing to a commit and does not exist and we could not update it. I updated the way we try to update (I tested and specifying the branch was not needed but I still like it so I left it in) and adding `--remote` does indeed updates to the most recent commit and avoids the issue. Because the files inside are automatically checkout we don't accidentally add the whole wiki inside the generator. But I'm not sure if ignoring them will be fine yet. I'm still familiarizing myself with the code and there is a long script that commits the changes among other things that I didnt include into the package (too big), I have yet to fully study that one, it seems to be the last thign to do after changes are made and shipped

Well, our wiki is heavily moderated and it requires some reviews to commit to it. Even if I am a mod, I  still have to submit my contribution for peer review by at least 2-3 mods other than me.

The standard process is that you fork the repo, clone the fork, go add a branch locally, add your changes in that branch, then push the branch to your fork - and finally raise a PR from there.

Now the pr undergoes review - and after you fix changes suggested by us, your PR gets merged.

git pull-request

# How to take someone's PR and make your own base dof it whilie keeping his commit

1. Make a new branch, preferibly with the PR# of the original one like `git checkout -b pr/574`
2. Pull his changes to it `git pull git://github.com/raisedadead/wiki.git update/translations-guide`
3. Make your changes, add, commit, push. If you need to squash make sure to keep the original contributor's commit untouched.
4. Create your PR and in the description make it to close the original PR with `closes #574`

@alayek  @Rafase282 As per **jdalton** — *the lodash guy!*, there are many cases where browser's native, the so called "optimized" functions are slower than lodash bcoz of too many quirky checks and fallbacks. Lodash is very highly perfomant and it uses loops and sparingly uses natives wherever relevant unlike underscore (*which was heavy on native functions*). It is best to use lodash as it has got a lot many improvements and strategies like lazy evaluation to make the code run faster and in an optimum way. :rocket:

# Wiki Labels Guide
Labels help in categorizing [**issues**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/issues) and [**pull requests**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/pulls). Use **_issue_ only** labels for issues and **_PR_ only** labels for pull requests.

This needs to be done for all the algoritm solutions, and we need people to help transfer the content to the new format and guidelines.

@Scoodood the template is an upgraded version, we don't want 5 or 6 solutions, we feel that 3 solutions, one per category is enough. After all, there is not fixed answer to the challenges and they are there for reference to help those having trouble. The categories are beginer, intermediate and advanced solutions.

Also clear explanations of the code are required, not just inline comments. Furthermore, if you want to add a solution, you need to select which category it should go, if it is similar but you feel your solution will add more then you should combine both into one, meaning improve with the new changes from yours. If your solution is better in all regards then you can replace the existing solution for yours.

# Wiki Labels Guide
Labels help in categorizing [**issues**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/issues) and [**pull requests**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/pulls). Use **_issue_ only** labels for issues and **_PR_ only** labels for pull requests. Listed here are labels for [**FreeCodeCamp Wiki**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki) — see [*wiki source*](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki) and [*wiki labels*](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels).

Labels | Description | Use in Issue | Use in PR
:---|:---:|:---:|:---:
[**![Label: QA](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-QA-0052cc.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: QA")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/QA) | Content Review :book: | :x: | :white_check_mark: 
[**![Label: help wanted](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-help_wanted-159818.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: help wanted")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/help wanted) | Need help :heavy_plus_sign: in creating the article(s) | :white_check_mark: | :x: 
[**![Label: content update](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-content_update-eb6420.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: content update")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/content update) | Update non-code contents :up: of article(s) | :x: | :white_check_mark:
[**![Label: enhancement](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-enhancement-30A9DE.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: enhancement")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/enhancement) | Enhance codes or algos :memo: in article(s) | :x: | :white_check_mark:
[**![Label: WORK NEEDED:](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-WORK_NEEDED:-f9a11b.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: WORK NEEDED:")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels) | Work needed :construction_worker: on article(s) | :x: | :white_check_mark:
[**![Label: LANG:](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-LANG:-03a6ff.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: LANG:")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels) | Coding Language :scroll:  specific article(s) | :white_check_mark: | :white_check_mark:
[**![Label: in progress](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-in_progress-3ac569.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: in progress")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/in progress) | The author's WIP :construction: article(s) | :x: | :white_check_mark: 
[**![Label: Translation](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-Translation-0052cc.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: Translation")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/Translation) | Translation :speech_balloon: related article(s) | :white_check_mark: | :white_check_mark:
[**![Label: bug](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-bug-fc2929.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: bug")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/bug) | Bugs :bug: related to Wiki  | :white_check_mark: | :x:
[**![Label: blocked](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-blocked-000000.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: blocked")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/blocked) | Stale article(s) or author doesn't respond :no_good: | :x: | :white_check_mark: 
[**![Label: question](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-question-cc317c.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: question")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/question) | It is a question :question: | :white_check_mark: | :x: 
[**![Label: invalid](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-invalid-E53A40.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: invalid")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/invalid) | Not fit for Wiki :no_entry_sign: | :white_check_mark: | :white_check_mark: 
[**![Label: duplicate](https://img.shields.io/badge/Label-duplicate-D499B9.svg?style=flat-square&maxAge=2592000 "Label: duplicate")**](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/labels/duplicate) | Similar or Duplicate of each other :busts_in_silhouette: | :white_check_mark: | :white_check_mark:

@theflametrooper `wontfix` label as of now is never used in wiki as **Everything** is *fixable* in Wiki. ;)

@theflametrooper the `in progress` label is used if the author or the **PR** is still working on the PR and submitting commits from time to time.
@theflametrooper any translation related PR/issue can be labelled as `Translation`
@theflametrooper u label an issue or PR as `invalid` if the issue/PR is not fit for the Wiki
@theflametrooper if an issue is a Question, then label it as `question`
@theflametrooper btw, NOTE that u use  `content-update` and `algorithm` carefully. DON'T get confused. Choose wisely :innocent:
@theflametrooper `Duplicate` label is to mark any further issues or PRs which are duplicate of any previously filed PR/issue.
:+1: lol
@theflametrooper the `Bug` & `Help Wanted` labels are primarily used on Issues (not with PRs)
@theflametrooper then there are Language specific labels which are used on PRs or Issues which relate to any specific language.
@theflametrooper Label: `algorithm` is used for any `code` related modifications in any existing articles
@theflametrooper Label: `content update` is used for new articles or any non-markdown formatting changes i.e. any actual content modifications of existing article

Hi all!  When it comes to contributing to the Wiki, is it a bad idea to include code that could complete the challenge?  The reason I ask is that Quincy suggested I write about how I approached the URL-shortener back-end challenge.  I figured one of the biggest hurdles for people getting started with those projects is feeling overwhelmed with all of the new tools and ways of thinking that are required.  I'd be happy to write a full, slow, explanatory walkthrough using Express for the project so folks can at least get their feet wet.  I just didn't know if that would be viewed as simply handing the solution to them.

@SaintPeter good question! If you notice Quincy's original article on why we are expanding to other back-end languages; it was to help those who already have some familiarity with those and would rather hone their back-end skills on what they already somewhat know.

So far, we haven't assumed any prior knowledge in the language in creating most of the articles. Yes, we have assumed that they are looking at Wiki now, because they know some programming, some HTML-CSS etc.
IE:  An entire semester or more at a traditional college.
Obviously we can't be everything to everyone, but some of these language concepts are quite in-depth.
Or do we assume a complete novice?
IE:  Should we say "This is how it works in JS, this is how Lang X differs"?

### Point of Discussion
What "level" are the non-Javascript language articles written for?  Do we assume a complete programming beginner, or are we assuming someone who knows JS already?

## :point_right: [writing great git commit message  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/writing-great-git-commit-message)
### The seven rules of a great git commit message

1. Separate subject from body with a blank line
2. Limit the subject line to 50 characters
3. Capitalize the subject line
4. Do not end the subject line with a period
5. Use the imperative mood in the subject line
6. Wrap the body at 72 characters
7. Use the body to explain what and why vs. how

**A properly formed git commit subject line should always be able to complete the following sentence:**

> If applied, this commit will *`<<your subject line here>>`*

The problem with doing a hard reset is that the history will be rewritten

```
origin  git@github.com:FreeCodeCamp/wiki.git (fetch)
origin  git@github.com:FreeCodeCamp/wiki.git (push)
upstream        git@github.com:FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp.wiki.git (fetch)
upstream        git@github.com:FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp.wiki.git (push)

```
the local is the other way around
that is for the "live"

```
origin  git@github.com:FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp.wiki.git (fetch)
origin  git@github.com:FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp.wiki.git (push)
upstream        git@github.com:FreeCodeCamp/wiki.git (fetch)
upstream        git@github.com:FreeCodeCamp/wiki.git (push)

```
@Rafase282 :point_up: [April 11, 2016 6:23 PM](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Wiki?at=570b9e3bed3ca84d52ae8e46)

**First set this in your Live wiki directory**
```sh
# do this and see what the remote urls point to
git remote -v

# if origin or upstream remotes doesn't exist, then use `add` instead of `set-url`
git remote set-url origin <live repo url>
git remote set-url upstream <wiki repo url>

# ensure that you're in master branch
git checkout master
```

----
**Then this is your script**
```sh
LIVEWIKI="C:\Users\rafas\Documents\FreeCodeCamp.wiki"
cd $LIVEWIKI
git fetch upstream master # fetch from wiki "repo"
git reset --hard upstream/master # hard reset to wiki repo master
git push -f origin master # force push to live wiki
```
for that script, local = wiki repo, live = FCC's wiki
hesistating about doing a reset --hard
[![2016-04-11.png](https://files.gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Wiki/PbCa/thumb/2016-04-11.png)](https://files.gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Wiki/PbCa/2016-04-11.png)

```bash
#!/bin/bash

# Setup paths
LOCALWIKI="C:\Users\rafas\Documents\fcc-wiki"
LIVEWIKI="C:\Users\rafas\Documents\FreeCodeCamp.wiki"

echo "FreeCodeCamp Wiki updater v1"
echo
echo "Move to Local Wiki directory at " + $LOCALWIKI
cd $LOCALWIKI
echo
echo "Updating local repository..."
git pull
git status
echo
echo "Done!"
echo "Going to the live Wiki ..."
cd $LIVEWIKI
echo
echo "Update live wiki..."
git fetch upstream
git pull upstream master
git push
echo "Done!"
echo
# Keep the windows Open until I press a key
echo "Press any key to close this windows..."
read -n 1 -s
```

## :point_right: [writing great git commit message  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/writing-great-git-commit-message)
### The seven rules of a great git commit message

1. Separate subject from body with a blank line
2. Limit the subject line to 50 characters
3. Capitalize the subject line
4. Do not end the subject line with a period
5. Use the imperative mood in the subject line
6. Wrap the body at 72 characters
7. Use the body to explain what and why vs. how

**A properly formed git commit subject line should always be able to complete the following sentence:**

> If applied, this commit will *`<<your subject line here>>`*

:pencil: [read more about writing great git commit message on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/writing-great-git-commit-message)

- Parameters VS Variables

**Online Offline Editors**
**There are several offline IDE that programmers use in order to stay more
productive to learn and be more productive at work**


1.Eclipse is a free editor that is both online and offline incorporates Java,
C/C++, JavaScript, and PHP by IBM. Its *biggest advantages are code completion
by tabbing method which saves a lot of time writing documentations. 

It has a build in syntax check to fix any mistype words while coding a project. All of
features we've come to expect of an IDE are their code completion, templates,
integration with various SCMSs, and integration with build systems. 

Its code formatting and cleanup tools are very powerful. I find its build system to work
well and intuitively. I think these are the things upon which its reputation
is really built. Furthermore it has a refactoring that find and replace
function, variables and classes of a specific work. 

Eclipse offers more plugins, platforms, frameworks, and simpler to use compare 
to other IDE such as IntelliJ, BlueJ and JEdit.

2.NetBeans is a free intuitive editor that does it all compared from other IDE.
It has simple Swing GUI design tool to build user interfaces by dragging and
dropping components for instance buttons, textboxes. 

The disadvantage it is that with all its features it is slow to load and uses 
more memory than other IDEтАЩs.

3.IntelliJ IDEA it is the most efficient offline editor however it is not free.
It is faster than most editors however it has numbers of problems. Some major
advantages is using too much memory from system,

4.BlueJ is a simple editor mostly used to teach java and object oriented
programming. The main advantage of the editor over other ones is that it does
not need a main method to run the program.

**However there are several differences between online editors and the offline
editors**

1.CodeRun Studio is an online IDE that you build web application. It allows you
to run and test code online. It supports PHP, AJAX, and ASP.NET but there is a
14 days trial then it must be paid. It is difficult to save your project since
you must pay in order to fully operate it. ┬а
┬а
An offline IDE will be more beneficial to a programmer rather than an online
IDE due to the fact that large projects will slow down and that a software
team will need a reasonable office internet service. If there is a major storm
the connection will be affected causing many projects to be unfinished and
incomplete. 

The only advantages of online IDE is that projects can be access everywhere; 
there are no setup and configurations. There is no hardware limitation since 
all information will be stores in cloud.

┬а

I personally delete them, sometimes I even delete the whole fork and make a new one if I can't update without a merge. This is to avoid submiting a PR that has a merge on it with changes already merged.

After your PR was merge, it is recommended that you delete your branch and update your fork to include the latest version from FCC.

If you want to keep the branch you can, as long as it is up to date we our master, otherwise plenty of conflicts will show up resulting in a bad experience for you and us.

## :point_right: [official free code camp chat rooms  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/official-free-code-camp-chat-rooms)
The following are our official chat rooms.    

**Please note that all chat rooms listed here are publicly accessible and indexed by search engines, so only share email addresses or other sensitive information in private messages.**    

| Chat Room | Description |    
| --- | --- |    
| [FreeCodeCamp](https://gitter.im/freecodecamp/FreeCodeCamp) | our main chat room - hang out and chat about life and learning to code |    
| [Help](https://gitter.im/freecodecamp/Help) | get help with our HTML, CSS and jQuery challenges from your fellow campers |   
| [HelpJavaScript](https://gitter.im/freecodecamp/HelpJavaScript) | get help with our JavaScript and algorithm challenges from your fellow campers |    
| [HelpFrontEnd](https://gitter.im/freecodecamp/HelpFrontEnd) | get help with our front end projects from your fellow campers |    
| [HelpDataViz](https://gitter.im/freecodecamp/HelpDataViz) | get help with our data visualization projects from your fellow campers |    
| [HelpBackEnd](https://gitter.im/freecodecamp/HelpBackEnd) | get help with our back end projects from your fellow campers |    
| [Python](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/python) | get help doing our back end projects in Python, from your fellow campers |    
| [Java](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/java) | get help doing our back end projects in Java, from your fellow campers |    
| [Ruby](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/ruby) | get help doing our back end projects in Ruby, from your fellow campers |    
| [PHP](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/php) | get help doing our back end projects in PHP, from your fellow campers |  
| [Go](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/go) | get help doing our back end projects in Go, from your fellow campers | 
| [Elixir](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/elixir) | get help doing our back end projects in Elixir, from your fellow campers |
| [.NET](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/dotnet) | get help doing our back end projects in Microsoft .NET framework, from your fellow campers |
| [Linux](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/linux) | get help with using Linux, from your fellow campers |

## :point_right: [writing great git commit message  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/writing-great-git-commit-message)
### The seven rules of a great git commit message

1. Separate subject from body with a blank line
2. Limit the subject line to 50 characters
3. Capitalize the subject line
4. Do not end the subject line with a period
5. Use the imperative mood in the subject line
6. Wrap the body at 72 characters
7. Use the body to explain what and why vs. how

**A properly formed git commit subject line should always be able to complete the following sentence:**

> If applied, this commit will *`<<your subject line here>>`*

## :point_right: [writing great git commit message  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/writing-great-git-commit-message)
### The seven rules of a great git commit message

1. Separate subject from body with a blank line
2. Limit the subject line to 50 characters
3. Capitalize the subject line
4. Do not end the subject line with a period
5. Use the imperative mood in the subject line
6. Wrap the body at 72 characters
7. Use the body to explain what and why vs. how

**A properly formed git commit subject line should always be able to complete the following sentence:**

> If applied, this commit will *`<<your subject line here>>`*

:pencil: [read more about writing great git commit message on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/writing-great-git-commit-message)

## :point_right: [git resources  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/git-resources)
> Resources for working with Git VCS

# Books and Tutorials
- [Pro Git](https://git-scm.com/book) - The entire Pro Git book, written by Scott Chacon and Ben Straub and published by Apress, is available here. Download this book in PDF, mobi, or ePub form for free.
- [Become a git guru - Atlassian](https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/) - Responsive site with Git tutorials, training and articles.
- [Git In The Trenches](http://cbx33.github.io/gitt/) - Git In The Trenches, or GITT is designed to be a book that focusses on teaching people to use Git by associating with scenarios that are experienced by a fictional company called Tamagoyaki Inc. Download this book in PDF, mobi, or ePub form for free.
- [Official Git Tutorial](https://git-scm.com/docs/gittutorial) - This tutorial explains how to import a new project into Git, make changes to it, and share changes with other developers.
- [Official Git User Manual](https://git-scm.com/docs/user-manual.html) - This manual is designed to be readable by someone with basic UNIX command-line skills, but no previous knowledge of Git.


# Other Resources
- [Git Ready](http://gitready.com) - 'Learn git one commit at a time' by Nick Quaranto
- [Hub](https://hub.github.com/) - Hub is a command-line wrapper for git that makes you better at GitHub.

@alanbuchanan Steps for making changes
- `git checkout master`
- `git pull -r"preserve" upstream master`
- `git checkout -b <new-branch name> master` OR `git branch <new branch> && git checkout <new branch>`
- Make changes to file
- `git add -p <changed file>`
- `git commit` (in editor, write headline, then a blank line, then body of commit)
- `git push -u origin <current branch>`

## :point_right: [writing great git commit message  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/writing-great-git-commit-message)
### The seven rules of a great git commit message

1. Separate subject from body with a blank line
2. Limit the subject line to 50 characters
3. Capitalize the subject line
4. Do not end the subject line with a period
5. Use the imperative mood in the subject line
6. Wrap the body at 72 characters
7. Use the body to explain what and why vs. how

**A properly formed git commit subject line should always be able to complete the following sentence:**

> If applied, this commit will *`<<your subject line here>>`*

## :point_right: [git rebase  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/git-rebase)
**Were you referred to this page to get your PR accepted? Scroll right [to the bottom](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/git-rebase#git-rebase-at-fcc) then!**

`git rebase` is an extremely useful tool that is all about rewriting git history, though most commonly used to *squash* multiple commits into one. While useful in this scenario, this is not the only function that the `git rebase` command can perform. It in fact proves to be far more useful when used for the intended function that its name suggests: to essentially *rebase* a branch. Let me explain what I mean by that.

Let us say that you have a repository such as this:

```
                                                  --- Commit 5 ----------- auth branch
                                                /               
                                               --- Commit 4 -------------- dev branch 
                                             /
 --- Commit 1 ---- Commit 2 ---- Commit 3 -------------------------------- master branch
```

If you wanted to merge the `auth` branch with the `dev` branch, git will throw an error at you because your `auth` branch is out-of-date: it doesn't account for Commit 4. You'll have to bring your branch up-to-date.

Git provides you with two methods to do this: the `merge` command and the `rebase` command. For an exploration of the `merge` command, visit the relevant wiki article: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/git-merge

Let's run `rebase` now:
```

```bash
#!/bin/bash
#

if [ "$1" = "-h" ]; then
     echo "Script to update the local and live version of the FreeCodeCamp wiki"
     echo "Usage: Update-Wiki.sh full_path_to_config.sh "
     echo "Example ~/Desktop/config.sh"
     sleep 3
	 exit 0
elif [ "$1" = "-help" ]; then
     echo "Script to update the local and live version of the FreeCodeCamp wiki"
     echo "Usage: Update-Wiki.sh full_path_to_config.sh "
     echo "Example ~/Desktop/config.sh"
     sleep 3
	 exit 0
elif [ "$1" = "" ]; then
     echo "Undefined parameters"
     echo "Usage: Update-Wiki.sh full_path_to_config.sh "
     echo "Example ~/Desktop/config.sh"
     sleep 3
	 exit 1
fi
configPath=$1

source $configPath

function exit {
  exit
}

function p {
  echo $1
}

function update {
  git pull
}

function status {
  git status
}

function commit {
  git add .
  git rm .
  git commit -m $1
  p Done!
}

function updateLive {
  cd $1
  git fetch $2
  git pull $2 $3
  git push
  p Done!
}

echo "FreeCodeCamp Wiki updater v1"
echo
echo "Move to Local Wiki directory at " + $workspace$local_wiki
cd $workspace$local_wiki
echo
echo "Updating local repository..."
update
status
echo
echo "Done!"
echo "Going to the live Wiki ..."
cd $workspace$live_wiki
echo
echo "Update live wiki..."
updateLive $workspace$live_wiki $up $down
status
echo "Done!"
echo

# Keep the windows Open until I press a key
echo "Press any key to close this windows..."
#read -n 1 -s
sleep 5
exit 0

```

## :point_right: [bonfire caesars cipher  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/bonfire-caesars-cipher)
# Problem Explanation:
- You need to write a function, which will take string encoded with
*Caesar cipher* as a parameter and decode it.
- The one used here is ROT13 where the value of the letter is
shifted by 13 places.
e.g. 'A' тЖФ 'N', 'T' тЖФ 'G'.
- You have to shift it back 13 positions, such that 'N' тЖФ 'A'.

:pencil: [read more about bonfire caesars cipher on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/bonfire-caesars-cipher)

## :point_right: [js array prototype slice  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/js-array-prototype-slice)
# Array.prototype.slice()

> The `slice()` method returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array into a new array object.

```js
arr.slice([begin[, end]])
```

| Necessity | Parameter | Description                                                          |
|-------------------|-----------|----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Required          | arr  | An Array object. |
| Required          | begin    | The beginning of the specified portion of array.                     |
| Optional          | end  | The end of the specified portion of array. |

**Return:** The slice method returns an *Array object* containing the specified portion of arrayObj.

[MDN link](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/slice) | [MSDN link](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/tkcsy6fe%28v=vs.94%29.aspx?f=255&MSPPError=-2147217396)

:pencil: [read more about js array prototype slice on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/js-array-prototype-slice)

## :point_right: [coding help [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/coding-help) # Coding Help I started this list while doing bonfires, noticing a few things that were common issues / questions but I think most of them are going to be useful to people coding in general. If you've got some tips to help people code I'd love to hear them. 1. If you don't know where to start, write some pseudocode. Plan out the logic you're trying to implement in your native language before you try to put it into code. 2. Comment your code! Can't stress that one enough, if you get lost or take a break then come back you need to know what your code is trying to do. It will also reinforce what the code means to you, and help other people understand what your code does if you get stuck and ask for help. If you've got a any other tips for campers I'd love to see them! 3. Use the chrome javascript debugger console in conjunction with something like netbeans IDE or sublime text to write your code. Both are free to download.
The free code camp window is great but you can get a lot more feedback on your code's behaviour by using chrome's JS debugger and a bunch of **console.log(myVariableGoesHere);**
https://developer.chrome.com/devtools/docs/console
http://www.sublimetext.com/
https://netbeans.org/downloads/ 4. Posting your code in gitter is as simple as adding a line consisting of only > \`\`\` > > Then your code on the next lines, followed by a final > > \`\`\` :pencil: [read more about coding help on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/coding-help)

## :fire:[Bonfire: Factorialize a Number](www.freecodecamp.com/challenges/bonfire-factorialize-a-number) :link:
```js 
function factorialize(num) {
  return num;
}

factorialize(5);```
Return the factorial of the provided integer.
If the integer is represented with the letter n, a factorial is the product of all positive integers less than or equal to n.
Factorials are often represented with the shorthand notation n!
For example: 5! = 1 * 2 * 3 * 4 * 5 = 120f
Remember to use [RSAP](//github.com/FreeCodeCamp/freecodecamp/wiki/How-to-get-help-when-you-get-stuck) if you get stuck. Try to pair program. Write your own code.
